summary.p: [Hieronymus] Gemus채us fell ill after his return from Italy and Savoy and died on January 19, which represents a significant loss for the university; Myconius succeeded in his application for the theological professorship against Cellarius [Martin Borrhaus]; in Strasbourg, there is no longer any hope for the ailing Paulus Lacisius. Emperor [Charles V] is on his way to Speyer, but it is questionable whether the Diet will take place; some signs indicate new troop recruitments by the Emperor. [Kaspar] Hedio hopes to soon become a preacher in Mainz, as he expects much from the Archbishop of Mainz [Albrecht of Brandenburg]; the bishops of Cologne and M체nster [Hermann of Wied and Franz of Waldeck] remain steadfast in the Gospel despite the Emperor's presence. Request for a response to [No. 1839]; greetings. Request for forwarding a letter from Strasbourg.

div.p: Greetings. Alas, our Gemus채us fell into a severe fever after his return from Italy and Savoy and was not in his right mind for several days, and on January 19, he breathed his last, not without the lament of many. Thus the Lord deals with our school, taking away the best among us. The proud and arrogant men now reign. Cellarius sought the theological lecture, as did our Myconius; but Myconius achieved what he wanted with the deputies.
What more shall I add? But I do not wish to stir up trouble. In Strasbourg, Paulus Lacisius, an Italian professor of Greek, is gravely ill, so much so that the doctors have despaired of his recovery.

The Emperor is on his way to Speyer. Some believe there will be no Diet, as everything is proceeding so coldly. The Spanish and Italian merchants, who are stuck with us, are giving money to reach Milan. I hear from some that the Emperor is recruiting a new army. There is a multitude of captains with us who have so far defended the French territories; what they intend, whether they are gathering soldiers, which seems likely, I do not know. I wanted to inform you of these few things, so that I might write something to you.

Furthermore, I do not want to keep this from you: Hedio hopes to soon become a preacher in Mainz, as he has conceived such hope from the Archbishop of Mainz. Would that he might end his life in the Lord, which is very aged! The bishops of Cologne and M체nster continue vigorously in proclaiming the Gospel even in the presence of the Emperor. May the Lord strengthen them with His spirit.

Farewell in the Lord, and if you have leisure, respond most fully to the next letters. You will greet D. Theodor in my name most dutifully. If you wish to share this with Vadianus, you will impart many greetings to him.
I would like you to ensure that the enclosed letters are delivered to the person whose address they bear; for they were sent to me from Strasbourg and I was instructed to send them to Zurich.
To the pious and learned Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, pastor of the church in Zurich, etc. Zurich.
